entry.title: Combined summary - Does Bitcoin require or have an honest majority or a rational one? (re rbf) (Jeremy Rubin)
entry.summary: The context discusses the potential negative impact of replace-by-fee (RBF) on Bitcoin, despite only a small percentage of transactions using it. Transactions can be replaced without warning, making it difficult for merchants to monitor and enforce 0conf acceptance. While responsible 0conf acceptance is rational and trusting, RBF enforcement is not reliable in ensuring the integrity of payments. However, some argue that RBF is necessary for optimal fee discovery and that most hashing power supports opt-in RBF. Rejecting blocks containing double-spends could lead to severe consensus problems, even though it should be implemented. The establishment's push for RBF continues to have negative consequences on more popular use cases. Carvalho suggests that facilitating replaceability for all transactions may be a better solution to prevent uncertainty indefinitely, even if it requires some to reassess their business approach.
